texts.shortText: Fairly large, tall wader with long, slightly-recurved, dark-grey bill. Upper parts white with dense black streaks. Wings darker towards flight feathers. Back, rump and underparts white. Legs distinctively pale olive-green.
Total length 30-33 cm, wingspan 68-70 cm, mass 170 g, sexes alike.

Global: Breeds in northern hemisphere, across both Europe and Asia. Summer migrant to Africa, India and Australia.

Local/Regional: Widespread across whole region, both inland and along the coast, but least common in arid areas.

Migrates from Europe in the southern summer, arriving in August-September and leaving again in March-April. Found both along gravel or sandy margins of inland waters, such as dams, riverbeds, ponds, salt-works etc., in estuaries and lagoons, and along both rocky and sandy seashores. Usually solitary, but sometimes in loose groups, moving constantly and following the tides, either along water margin or wading in shallows. Most prey caught by picking rather than probing, also by scything the bill from side to side with tip on surface.
Takes a variety of crabs, shrimps, sand and mudprawns, polychaetes and small fish.

Does not breed on South Africa, but in northern latitudes. Monogamous, but usually pair up with new mate each season. Lay 3-4 light cream eggs, which are heavily marked with darker brown splotches, from April to June. Nest a scrape on the ground close to solid structures, such as rocks, logs or trees. Incubation takes 23-26 days.
Green legs and upturned bill fairly distinctive. Marsh sandpiper also has green legs, but is much smaller and has a thin, straight bill.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 346).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robertâ€™s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 354).
